block.p: In Essex, Ships Ahoy!

Essex takes to the Sound on Friday and Saturday as host of the 25th Annual Traditional Vessels Weekend, the Governor's Cup Regatta and Classic Yacht Rendezvous. A welcome party is scheduled on Friday from 6 to 9 p.m. at the Connecticut River Museum, offering cocktails, barbecue and sea chanteys for $20 a person. Call (860) 767-8269 for tickets.
In Essex, Ships Ahoy!

Essex takes to the Sound on Friday and Saturday as host of the 25th Annual Traditional Vessels Weekend, the Governor's Cup Regatta and Classic Yacht Rendezvous. A welcome party is scheduled on Friday from 6 to 9 p.m. at the Connecticut River Museum, offering cocktails, barbecue and sea chanteys for $20 a person. Call (860) 767-8269 for tickets.

The Governor's Cup race heads out from Fenwick in Old Saybrook on Saturday at 10:30 a.m. Viewing is best from the Knollwood Beach area in Old Saybrook. At 1 p.m., spectators on the museum dock can watch the cats and gaffers race in Essex harbor.

From 6 to 11 p.m. on Saturday there will be cocktails at the museum followed by a New England clambake, lobster and steak dinner, dancing and presentation of racing awards at the Essex Corinthian Yacht Club. The tab is $40 a person with a cash bar. For reservations, race registration or more information call (860) 767-8269.
Oysters, Oysters, Oysters

It's September and that means the 23rd Annual Norwalk Seaport Association's Oyster Festival at Veteran's Park in South Norwalk is on the way. Hours on Friday are 5 to 11 p..m., Saturday 10 a.m. to 11 p.m., and next Sunday 10 to 9.

Oysters are ubiquitous in many cooked and uncooked permutations but they are only one of the edibles offered in the International Food Court. Aside from food, a list of entertainers and special features grows with each passing year.
The Four Tops and the Village People head the list of performers on Friday, to be followed on stage each day by a stream of singers and musicians representing many ethnic disciplines.
Twenty-two sky divers will drop at 125 miles an hour from 7,000 feet on Friday and Saturday, and the Zambellis will stage fireworks displays after dark on both days.

More than 200 exhibitors will display a wide variety of fine art and crafts, and an exhibition of grown-up toys includes motorcycles, race cars, watercraft, home gyms and theaters, hot tubs, wireless communications gizmos and computers.

A section called Kids' Cove will keep children busy for hours boarding a replica of Theodore Tugboat, from the children's television show. The children can climb on rides, listen to storytellers, and see a collection of live animals including a mountain lion cub, alligator, python, owl and peregrine falcon.
Admission will be $8 for adults, $5 for older adults, $3 for children 6 through 12 and free for those under 6. Call (203) 838-9444 for more information.
Benefit Horse Show
Competition at the 4-H Nutmeg Benefit Horse Show begins next Sunday at 8:30 a.m., running through mid-afternoon at UConn's Agricultural Extension Center, 67 Stony Hill Road (Route 6) in Bethel.

Awards will be presented to winners in the Kentucky Hunter, Beginner Hunter, Western and Junior Western Divisions. Spectators are welcome and food will be available on the grounds. For directions or more information call (203) 207-8440.
Organ Music Festival

Awards of $250 to $2,000 will be distributed to winners of the Albert Schweitzer Organ Festival competition for high school and college students. The event is held annually at the First Church of Christ, 250 Main Street in Wethersfield, open to the public.

Works by Bach, Durufle and Widor will be performed on Friday at 7 p.m. by the festival choir and guest organists Frederick Hohman and Paul Fejko, competition judges. High school finalists Tamara Logan, Andrew Hauze and Jacinta Whittaker will appear on Saturday from 9 to noon, followed by college finalists Mark Cole, Christian Lane and Iain Quinn from 2 to 5 p.m. Awards will be presented next Sunday at 4 p.m. Mr. Quinn of Hartford is the only Connecticut finalist.
Admission is free but donations will be received. For directions or more information call (860) 563-7759.
Impressionism in Hartford

During the early 1870's six artists gathered in Argenteuil, a suburb of Paris known for its gypsum mines that produced plaster of Paris and for pleasure boating on the Seine. There they evolved the free-wheeling style of painting known as Impressionism.

An exhibition of 50 paintings of Argenteuil and its environs by Claude Monet, Auguste Renoir, Edouard Manet, Alfred Sisley, Gustave Caillebotte and Eugene Boudin, on loan from private collectors and major museums around the world opens on Saturday at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford, remaining through Dec. 3.
Monet involuntarily set the stage for symbiosis by moving to Argenteuil in 1871, where he was visited frequently by the others.

A 15-minute train ride from Paris gave them an opportunity to paint together en plein air, recording bridges and boulevards, sailboats and towpaths, gardens, factories and portraits of each other and of Monet's family.
The group flourished, producing a body of work substantial enough to be mounted publicly in 1874 as the first Impressionist Show, not in Paris but in Argenteuil.

Advance, timed tickets are required for admission on the hour and half-hour at $17 for adults, $15 for people 60 and older and students with identification, $13 for children 6 through 17 and free for children under 6. The Atheneum is located at 600 Main Street in downtown Hartford and exhibition hours are on Tuesday, Wednesday and Friday from 10:30 to 5, Thursday from 10:30 to 9, Saturday from 10 to 9 and Sunday from 10 to 6. The toll-free ticket number is (877) 600-MAIN (6246), or visit www. museumtix.com. Do not call the museum.
Early Model Automobiles

Saturday marks the 49th Fall Meet of the Fairfield County Region of The Horseless Carriage Club of The American and Antique Automobile Club of America. What that mouthful means is that from 10 to 4, more than 100 automoblies and motorcycles made before 1942 will be on display with their owners attired in costumes appropriate to the period of the vehicle.
An automotive flea market, a banjo band, children's activities and a food tent sponsored by The Brewhouse at New England Brewing Company in Norwalk will be available all day.

It all takes place on the grounds of the Lockwood-Mathews Mansion Museum, 295 West Avenue, Norwalk. Admission is $8, students and older adults $5, under 12 free. Call (203) 838-9799 for more information.
